title-group.article-title: Microglia and sexual differentiation of the developing brain: a focus on ontogeny and intrinsic factors

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Pediatrics, Lurie Center for Autism, Massachusetts General Hospital for Children, Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts, 02129, USA.
2Department of Psychology and Neuroscience, Duke University, Durham, North Carolina, 27708, USA.

author-notes.corresp: Address correspondence to: Staci Bilbo, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, staci.bilbo@duke.edu

abstract.p: Sexual differentiation of the brain during early development likely underlies the strong sex biases prevalent in many neurological conditions. Mounting evidence indicates that microglia, the innate immune cells of the central nervous system, are intricately involved in these sex-specific processes of differentiation. In this review, we synthesize literature demonstrating sex differences in microglial number, morphology, transcriptional state, and functionality throughout spatio-temporal development as well as highlight current literature regarding ontogeny of microglia. Along with vanRyzin et al in this issue, we explore the idea that differences in microglia imparted by chromosomal or ontogeny-related programming can influence microglial-driven sexual differentiation of the brain, as well as the idea that extrinsic differences in the male and female brain microenvironment may in turn impart sex differences in microglia.
